The European Species Action Plan for the Conservation of the Cinereous Vulture (2017) provides a comprehensive overview of the conservation and research actions necessary to conserve this species in Europe (Andevski et al. 2017). In addition to the above, the plan recommends: reintroducing or restoring wild ungulate populations; increasing the monitoring of poisoning of vultures; improving legal measures to reduce poisoning incidents; banning lead ammunition; and raising public awareness of the risks to Cinereous Vultures and the positives of maintaining vulture populations.

rationale: This species has an extremely large range, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the range size criterion (extent of occurrence <20,000 km<sup>2</sup> combined with a declining or fluctuating range size, habitat extent/quality, or population size and a small number of locations or severe fragmentation). Despite local declines, the global population trend appears to be increasing, and hence the species does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population trend criterion (>30% decline over 10 years or three generations). The population size is very large, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population size criterion (<10,000 mature individuals with a continuing decline estimated to be >10% in 10 years or three generations, or with a specified population structure). For these reasons the species is evaluated as Least Concern.
habitat: Behaviour Some birds are migratory, overwintering in Africa, although many others are resident or nomadic (del Hoyo et al. 1994). It relies heavily on soaring flight, and has been shown to fly at altitudes of 10,000 m and higher. Birds hunt alone but congregate at food sources and roosts; they also tend to migrate singly, but concentrations (usually up to 15 individuals) form at sea crossings and strong thermals (del Hoyo et al. 1994; Ferguson-Lees and Christie 2001). Habitat It is a species of expansive open areas in a wide array of environments, from mountains to semi-desert, and is recorded regularly from sea level up to c.3,000 m (del Hoyo et al. 1994). Diet It feeds almost exclusively on carrion, mainly that of large mammals (del Hoyo et al. 1994). Breeding site The nest is usually built on a rocky outcrop, with sheltered ledges or small caves preferred (del Hoyo et al. 1994). Management information Effective protection in areas with a plentiful supply of food (which often includes the carrion of domestic animals), has been shown to catalyse impressive population recoveries, and reintroduction has been successful in parts of its range (del Hoyo et al. 1994).
threats:
It declined markedly throughout the 19th–20th centuries in much of Europe, North Africa and the Middle East, mainly due to direct persecution and "bycatch" from the poisoned carcasses set for livestock predators (Snow and Perrins 1998, Ferguson-Lees and Christie 2001, Orta et al. 2015). Direct persecution has decreased, although it may still be a threat in eastern Europe, Central Asia and possibly the Middle East (Botha et al. 2017). Unintentional poisoning through poison bates remains the most significant threat to the species (Botha et al. 2017) - during 2000-2010 2,146 Griffon Vultures were found poisoned in Spain (RSPB 2014). In some areas a reduction in available food supplies, arising from changes in livestock management practices, also had an impact (Ferguson-Lees and Christie 2001, Orta et al. 2015). It is very highly vulnerable to the effects of potential wind energy development (Strix 2012) and electrocution has been identified as a threat (Global Raptors Information Network 2015). Disturbance caused by visitors may also pose a threat in some areas (Choresh et al. 2019). Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) used for veterinary purposes pose a threat to this species. One case of suspected poisoning caused by flunixin, an NSAID, was recorded in this species in 2012 in Spain (Zorrilla et al. 2015), and several more have occurred since (Herrero-Villar et al. 2020). Diclofenac, a similar NSAID which has caused severe declines in Gyps vulture species across Asia, was authorised for veterinary use in Spain in 2013. Diclofenac was detected in livestock carcasses in the Iberian Peninsula between 2013 and 2019 (Herrero-Villar et al. 2020), and in 2021 the first case of a vulture death in Europe due to ingestion of Diclofenac was confirmed (Herrero-Villar et al. 2021). 

There were widespread declines in the population of Griffon vultures throughout Portugal and the Iberian Peninsula during the 20th century (Carneiro et al. 2015). This is a result of the species ingesting toxins from the carcasses they feed on, which accumulate in their system and increase mortality rates. Most of the carcasses the species feeds on are high in toxins as they came through livestock management or hunting practises; lead bullet fragments are often ingested leading to a build-up of toxic levels of lead within the species. This was worsened in 2001 when the EU legislated against the disposal of livestock carcasses in the field to curb the spread of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease. This lowered food availability and forced some vultures to seek out food in areas including garbage dumps, where they risk ingesting further heavy metals. In an analysis of 121 wild vultures sampled on the Iberian Peninsula, every individual had lead present in its blood, ranging in concentration from 4.97 to 300.23 μg/dl. The declines are further worsened by the intentional, and illegal, poisoning of Griffon vultures, the largest cause of non-natural mortality in large birds of prey (Carneiro et al. 2015).
population: The European population is estimated at 34,800-44,700 pairs, which equates to 69,600-89,400 mature individuals (BirdLife International in prep.). Approximately 10% of the global range for this species falls within Europe, so a very preliminary estimate of the global population size is 696,000-894,000 mature individuals. However, Botha et al. (2017) estimate the population to be much smaller than this, at 80,000-120,000 individuals. It is placed in the band 80,000-900,000 mature individuals.
conservationActions:
Conservation actions underway
CITES Appendix II, CMS Appendix II, Raptors MOU Category 3, EU Birds Directive Annex I. Breeding schemes are in place in at least 8 European countries (Derlink et al. 2018). A Multi-species Action Plan to Conserve African-Eurasian Vultures was produced in 2017 (Botha et al. 2017). The species has been reintroduced to several countries in Europe, including France, Italy and the Balkans. Supplementary feeding also take place in several countries, and has successfully increased the breeding population in Serbia (Marinkovic et al. 2021). Several projects are underway to battle the threat of illegal poisoning, such as the BalkanDetox LIFE project (https://balkandetoxlife.eu/). 

Conservation Actions Proposed
Research the extent of poisoning by NSAIDs in Europe. Ensure enforcement of regulations imposed to avoid diclofenac intoxication in vultures. If necessary, implement a ban on veterinary use of diclofenac in Europe and promote vulture-safe alternatives. Continue monitoring population trends. Investigate the effect of human disturbance on colony size (Choresh et al. 2019). Identify threats outside of breeding areas. Continue to raise awareness and build capacity to fight illegal poisoning. Enforce legal consequences of illegal poisoning. For a comprehensive list of proposed conservation actions, see Botha et al. (2017).

rationale: Listed as Endangered its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,352 km<sup>2 </sup>and its area of occupancy (AOO) is smaller than 100 km<sup>2</sup>, its population is severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the extent and quality of its habitat on the island of Puerto Rico.
habitat:
It is a terrestrial species found in semi-arid, rocky areas of seasonal evergreen forests near the karst coasts (Schwartz and Henderson 1991).  Eggs are laid in permanent or temporary pools of water, streams, or small dams for livestock (Ross 2007). For the wild population of the GCF, metamorphosis occurs between 14 to 25 days (Canals-Mora, 1990).  Temperature and water level affect the time to metamorphosis (Cáceres-Charneco 2018). The GCF population breed in a temporary pond that is also affected by water salinity. Exposure to water salinity affects time to metamorphosis and survivorship (Cáceres-Charneco 2018). In the artificial rearing ponds, other abiotic factors like cooler temperatures and high pH could influence tadpoles (Cáceres-Charneco and Ortiz-Zayas 2019).  Other tadpole species that can be found in the ponds with P. lemur include the native Caribbean White Lipped frog (Leptodactylus albilabris) and the introduced giant marine toad (Rhinella marina).

After metamorphosis, metamorphs will gather close to the pond edge and can be found clustered under leaflitter or fallen logs (USFWS 2015).  Once toadlets leave the ponds, they move to the forest and search for refuges on limestone rock or holes in the ground (Pacheco and Barber 2013).  The longest distance travelled by metamorph was 14 to 19 m in one night (USFWS 2015). Juveniles have not been followed for longer periods than two months after they metamorphose and not much is known after they leave the pond (Cáceres-Charneco 2018).

As for adults, reproduction occurs shortly after heavy rainfall events (Canals-Mora 1990, Rivero 1998, Lugo et al. 2001). For the GCF population, most of their reproduction events occur during the wet season (August to November), but reproduction can also occur from mid spring until summer (April to July) (CBSG 2006 and M. Canals-Mora, published and unpublished data). The reintroduced populations in the north are not as precipitation limited as the southern population, as reproduction has been documented in El Tallonal and La Esperanza frequently.
threats:
Habitat loss due to urban expansion was probably a major threat to the historical and last documented locality on the north coast (Ross 2007; Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). There is some small-scale agriculture still taking place that could affect the species La Esperanza in Manatí (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). The passing of the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management, and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA) in 2016 to address Puerto Rico’s economic crisis has created a new level of uncertainty about the future of public protected areas on the island as control over decision-making is transferred from local authorities to an unelected board of financial managers (Snow 2017, Castro-Prieto et al. 2019). It is feared that this change might favour economic activities that will facilitate land use changes, driving the destruction and degradation of important habitats, and negatively impacting both biodiversity and human populations across Puerto Rico who depend on healthy and intact ecosystems for survival (Puerto Rico Red List Workshop June 2020).

The Caribbean region shows evidence of climate warming at regional (Peterson et al. 2002, Stephenson et al. 2014, IPCC 2018) and local scales (Burrowes et al. 2004, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). Precipitation patterns are not as clear, but some studies have shown a significant drying trend (Nurse et al. 2001, Neelin et al. 2006, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). Breeding events are related to heavy rainfall, any changes in rainfall patterns that lead to more drought events put the species' reproduction and survival at risk. The frequency of extreme events like hurricanes, heavy rains, landslides, and droughts has increased significantly in the last decade (Méndez-Lázaro et al. 2014, Oppenheimer et al. 2019) and may continue to rise in the future (IPCC 2014, 2018). Due to characteristics intrinsic to their biology and physiology, patterns of recent climate change in the Caribbean are expected to be unfavourable to this species. Climate warming and drought have been associated with a decrease in arthropods (Lister and Garcia 2018), an important food item for frogs; however, there have been doubts regarding the methodology used by Lister and Garcia (2018) (see Willig et al. 2019). The effects of climate change can also be associated with an increased risk of chytridiomycosis (Longo et al. 2010).

At the GCF, breeding events are threatened by the proximity of natural breeding ponds to the sea and by the historical and potentially ongoing intrusion of saltwater (Cáceres-Charneco 2018). Water salinity values over 6 ppt has adverse effects on the development and survival of tadpoles of this species (Cáceres-Charneco 2018). Due to its proximity to the sea, sea level rise associated with climate change is a concern for the subpopulations occurring at Tamarindo pond at GCF and Punta Ventana in Guayanilla (USFWS 2015). If individuals choose to breed at the main ponds at Tamarindo and salinity levels are high (i.e. 8 ppt), it is expected that the breeding events would have zero recruitment (R. Cáceres-Charneco pers. comm. 2020). Increasing salt water intrusion events (due to increasing sea level rise and tidal waves) could cause local extirpation of these subpopulations (R. Cáceres-Charneco, A. Puente and S. Vega pers. comms. 2020). Following Hurricane Maria in 2017, the Ciénaga wetlands in Yauco were flooded due to shifting hydrology resulting in destruction of this species' habitat (R. Cáceres-Charneco pers. comm. 2020).

In addition, competition and predation by the introduced giant marine toad (Rhinella marina) had been documented and identified as major threats, mainly on the metamorph stage (Flores-Vallejo 2011, Cáceres-Charneco 2018).
population:
The species was last recorded on Virgin Gorda Island in 1964 and surveys since then have not located any individuals. One individual was found on St. John (U.S. Virgin Islands) in 1978, but it is currently believed to be extirpated from the island (Norton 1997, 1998; Platenberg and Boulon 2006). In Puerto Rico, all naturally occurring subpopulations have been extirpated from the northern portion of the island since 1988 (Johnson 1999, Ross 2007), with only three reproductive subpopulations persisting in southwest Puerto Rico: Guanica Commonwealth Forest (GCF), Ciénaga wetland in Yauco, and Punta Ventana in Guayanilla (USFWS 2015, Barber et al. 2019). As part of the conservation strategies in place for this species, the Puerto Rican Crested Toad has been re-introduced at six localities within its historical range: three in northern Puerto Rico (El Tallonal in Arecibo, Río Encantado in Ciales/Florida and La Esperanza in Manatí) and three in southern Puerto Rico (Manglillo Grande within the GCF, Gabia Farm in Coamo and Cueva El Convento in Guayanilla).

Population estimates for the species have been derived mainly from anecdotal reports and the number of toads observed during reproductive events or single night surveys (USFWS 2015). By 1992, when the US Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) approved the recovery plan for the species, the population size was estimated at ca. 2,000 individuals (USFWS 1992). Between 1984 and 2016, 53 reproduction events were confirmed for the Tamarindo natural pond at GCF (Cáceres-Charneco 2018). The greatest number of toads reported in a single breeding event was 2,224 toads when G. Ross and M. Canals reported 1,444 males and 780 females at the GCF (USFWS 2015). Although there are no specific numbers, the population in GCF is considered stable based on the frequency of reproductive events and observations of individuals. The subpopulation at Punta Ventana in Guayanilla appears to be relatively stable because adults can found outside of the breeding season and during the dry season, however the population status needs to be verified by further surveys (R. Cáceres-Charneco and A. Puente pers. comms. 2020).

There are no population estimates for the six re-introduction sites, but acoustic monitoring efforts in four of these sites (El Tallonal, La Esperanza, Manglillo Grande and Cueva El Convento) during breeding events and tadpole release events indicate that species is successfully breeding thus far (R. Cáceres-Charneco, A. Puente and S. Vega pers. comms. 2020). In captivity, the population consists of about 900 adult toads on average (USFWS 2015).
range:
The Puerto Rican Crested Toad has been described as endemic to the Puerto Rican Bank, the island of Puerto Rico and Virgin Gorda in the British Virgin Islands. The species is considered to be Extinct at Virgin Gorda, however (Perry and Gerber 2006). Anecdotal reports suggest that the species also used to occur on the U.S. Virgin Islands of St. Thomas and St. John, and on the Isla de Vieques in Puerto Rico (USFWS 2015), however no museum specimens exist (R. Cáceres Charneco, A. Puente and S. Vega pers. comms. 2020). 

In Puerto Rico, its historical distribution is limited to the northern and southern karst regions, from sea level up to 50 m asl. Historically the species was collected from the municipalities of Bayamón, Vega Baja, Barceloneta, Arecibo, Quebradillas, Isabela, Coamo, Santa Isabel, Ponce, Guayanilla, Yauco, and Guánica (Schmidt 1928, Schwartz and Henderson 1991, Rivero 1998, Joglar 2005, USFWS 2015). Currently, the Puerto Rican Crested Toad is known from only three naturally occurring subpopulations along the southern coast of Puerto Rico, located less than 4 km apart: 1) Guanica Commonwealth Forest (GCF); 2) Ciénaga wetland in Yauco; and 3) Punta Ventana in Guayanilla (USFWS 2015; Barber et al. 2019). It has also been re-introduced at six sites: 1) El Tallonal in Arecibo; 2) Río Encantado in Ciales/Florida; 3) La Esperanza in Manatí (all in northern Puerto Rico); 4) Manglillo Grande within the GCF; 5) Gabia Farm in Coamo; and 6) Cueva El Convento (El Convento Natural Protected Area) in Guayanilla (all in southern Puerto Rico). The extent of occurrence (EOO), based on the distribution of the extant population, is 2,352 km2 and its area of occupancy (AOO) is smaller than 100 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The only naturally occurring population is restricted to southern Puerto Rico and divided in three subpopulations, with the largest subpopulation occurring within the GCF where the habitat is relatively well-managed through co-management of the community and the Puerto Rico Department of Natural and Environmental Resources (DNER). A captive breeding programme has been implemented since 1992, and over 500,000 tadpoles have been released into the reintroduced sites. Captive-born adults can often be observed using the artificial ponds for breeding and successful reproductive events has been documented in four of the six reintroduction sites (El Tallonal, Hacienda La Esperanza, Manglillo Grande and Cueva El Convento). The Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA) have maintained a healthy captive population since 1982 (USFWS 2015). Due to the threat posed by R. marina, adults of the Marine Toad are removed monthly from reintroduction sites (Barber et al. 2019). Since 2003, all conservation efforts are led by the Puerto Rican Crested Toad Working Group. The working group is directed by the DNER, USFWS and AZA, and supported by non-profit organizations and universities (USFWS 2015). 

Conservation Needed
Economic development should not be granted priority over currently federally protected natural resource areas in Puerto Rico and the protected status of such lands should be maintained (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). Recommended in-situ conservation actions include restoration of existing habitat and creation of new reintroduction sites and site management to mitigate the impact of saltwater intrusion at GCF ponds, such as relocation of tadpoles to other inland ponds. In view of the negative effects of anthropogenic climate change on this species and its habitat, national and global policies are needed to curb the use of and reliance on fossil fuels. In order to create awareness of the species, a formal education campaign in communities near reintroduction sites is needed (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Research Needed
Future research projects should include population estimates and occurrence; intensive, long-term monitoring at reintroduction sites and all natural breeding events, and monitoring of abiotic factors and usage of new artificial reproduction ponds at GCF. Incorporation of automated recording systems is needed to detect the species in inaccessible areas that are difficult to survey. More research is needed to better understand the species-specific response to the effects of climate change (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 7,695 km<sup>2</sup>, it is common and adaptable with a presumed large and stable population.
habitat: It is found in closed forest and open meadows. It also occurs in coastal grass-dominated wetlands in sympatry with Eleutherodactylus juanariveroi (N. Rios-López pers. comm. 2008). Eggs are laid on the ground, and they breed by direct development. It appears to be quite tolerant of habitat disturbance as demonstrated by its use of banana plantations, gardens, agricultural areas, and pastureland (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
threats:
There might be localized threats from infrastructure development and agriculture. The use of pesticides in agricultural areas could represent a threat to this species (R. Joglar pers. comm. 2020). 

This species is infected with the amphibian chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd), in the highlands of Carite State Forest and the Central Cordillera, in Toro Negro and Adjuntas (Burrowes et al. 2008). At the time of this assessment, chytridiomycosis is not considered a major threat to this species.

The passing of the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management, and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA) in 2016 to address Puerto Rico’s economic crisis has created a new level of uncertainty about the future of public protected areas on the island as control over decision making is transferred from local authorities to an unelected board of financial managers (Snow 2017, Castro-Prieto et al. 2019). It is feared that this change will favor economic activities that will facilitate land use changes, driving the destruction and degradation of important habitats, and negatively impacting both biodiversity and human populations across Puerto Rico who depend on healthy and intact ecosystems for survival (Puerto Rico Red List Workshop June 2020).

The Caribbean region shows evidence of climate warming at regional (Stephenson et al. 2014, IPCC 2018) and local scales (Burrowes et al. 2004, Bhardwaj et al. 2018). The frequency of extreme events like droughts and unreliable rains have increased significantly in the last decade (Méndez-Lázaro et al. 2014, Oppenheimer et al. 2019) and may continue to rise in the future (IPCC 2014, 2018). Due to characteristics intrinsic to their biology and physiology, patterns of recent climate change in the Caribbean are expected to be unfavorable to this species.

While some studies have shown that Small Indian Mongoose (Urva auropunctata) prey upon native coquis, only a small proportion (~1%) of their stomach contents include amphibians (Wolcott 1953, Pimentel 1955, Viella 1998). The introduced Cuban Tree Frog (Osteopilus septentrionalis) is a generalist predator that may include coquis in its diet, however the proportion of amphibians found in stomach content analysis (3.5%) is also low (Glorioso et al. 2010). This information suggests that the relative threat level of introduced predators on this species is low (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
population: It is abundant in suitable habitat and the population is considered to be stable.
range: This species is widespread in the interior of Puerto Rico and the uplands, from close to sea level up to 1,100 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 7,695 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-79409865-7fff-79b5-d3d4-106b64c7b45d">Generally, the species is not thought to be utilized by humans. However, an anecdote is known related to five illegally collected individuals of this species that were bound for Ohio (USA) for the pet trade, but were confiscated by authorities (R.L. Joglar unpubl data 2020). This is likely an isolated incident.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Its range includes several protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Economic development should not be granted priority over currently federally protected natural resource areas in Puerto Rico and the protected status of such lands should be maintained. Community education and awareness programmes aimed to generate knowledge of and appreciation for Puerto Rico's endemic amphibians are recommended (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Research Needed
Further research on this species' distribution, population size and trends, and natural history is recommended. More research is needed to better understand the species-specific response to the effects of climate change (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 313 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals occur in fewer than five locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in Batolito San Lorenzo y Humacao, Puerto Rico.
habitat: It has highly specialized habitat requirements, being found only in caves and rock grottos known as "guajonales" and in rocky stream banks covered with moss, ferns and other vegetation (Vega-Castillo 2000). Eggs are laid on damp boulder surfaces in grottoes, bamboo trunks and muddy substrates, and cared for by males and develop directly (Burrowes 2000, Longo et al. 2013). The area where this species occurs in the Icaco Valley is second-growth forest intermixed with line-planted timber trees, and few of the trees are over 30 years in age (Nelson et al. 2010). The presence of this frog in this area demonstrates that properly managed second-growth forests may play a role in conservation efforts of this species (Greenhawk 2013), as long as they are associated with granodiorite rock formations and perennial or ephemeral streams (A. Longo pers. comm. 2020).
threats:
All of this species' critical habitats are fragmented and confined to private lands (López-Torres and Longo 2013). The main threat to this species is habitat destruction that is taking place due to agricultural expansion, soil erosion, urban development, and issues with roadside pollution (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). The widespread use of herbicides and insecticides have also been posed as a threat to this species (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). 

The passing of the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management, and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA) in 2016 to address Puerto Rico’s economic crisis has created a new level of uncertainty about the future of public protected areas on the island as control over decision making is transferred from local authorities to an unelected board of financial managers (Snow 2017, Castro-Prieto et al. 2019). It is feared that this change might favor economic activities that will facilitate land use changes, driving the destruction and degradation of important habitats, and negatively impacting both biodiversity and human populations across Puerto Rico who depend on healthy and intact ecosystems for survival (Puerto Rico Red List Workshop June 2020).

This species is potentially susceptible to chytridiomycosis, as some subpopulations are associated with streams and the amphibian chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, has recently been recorded in this species (López-Torres and Longo 2013, Longo et al. 2020). Soft ticks (Carios spp.) have been found on this species and individuals were observed to be lethargic, but the severity of this threat remains unknown (Vega-Castillo 2000, Longo et al. 2020).

The Caribbean region shows evidence of climate warming at regional (Peterson et al. 2002, Stephenson et al. 2014, IPCC 2018) and local scales (Burrowes et al. 2004, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). Precipitation patterns are not as clear, but some studies have shown a significant drying trend (Nurse et al. 2001, Neelin et al. 2006, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). The frequency of extreme events like hurricanes, heavy rains, and droughts has increased significantly in the last decade (Méndez-Lázaro et al. 2014, Oppenheimer et al. 2019) and may continue to rise in the future (IPCC 2014, 2018). Due to characteristics intrinsic to their biology and physiology, patterns of recent climate change in the Caribbean are expected to be unfavorable to this species (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). Climate warming and drought have been associated with a decrease in arthropods (Lister and Garcia 2018), an important food item for frogs; however, there have been doubts regarding the methodology used by Lister and Garcia (2018) (see Willig et al. 2019). The effects of climate change can also be associated with an increased risk of chytridiomycosis (Longo et al. 2010).

While some studies have shown that Small Indian Mongoose (Urva auropunctata) prey upon native coquis, only a small proportion (~1%) of their stomach contents include amphibians (Wolcott 1953, Pimentel 1955, Viella 1998). The introduced Cuban Tree Frog (Osteopilus septentrionalis) is a generalist predator that may include coquis in its diet, however the proportion of amphibians found in stomach content analysis (3.5%) is also low (Glorioso et al. 2010). This information suggests that the relative threat level of introduced predators on this species is low (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
population: Population size is highly variable across critical habitats (A. Longo pers. comm. 2020). Adults and eggs were recorded in the Icaco Valley in 2011 and 2012 (Greenhawk 2013), but the species was not detected in one of its critical habitats (Unit 5 Jacaboa) in 2013 (Longo et al. 2020). It was observed in Juncos, Humacao, and Las Piedras in 2019, following Hurricane Maria, but occurred in lower abundances compared to pre-hurricane levels (S. Vega pers. comm. 2020). The species has been seen as recently as 2020, in the Sierra Pandura (O. Monzón pers comm. to R. Joglar 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species has a restricted distribution and it is exclusively associated with the geomorphologic region known as 'Batolito San Lorenzo y Humacao', which includes Sierra Pandura and lowlands of southeastern Puerto Rico. Its elevational range is 26–421 m asl (López‐Torres 2008), its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 313 km<sup>2</sup>, and all individuals occur in five or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
A small portion of the species' range occurs in Carite Forest, but most of its distribution is limited to privately owned lands. The Puerto Rican Conservation Trust, a local NGO, has acquired 70 ha securing some of the critical habitats for perpetuity (López-Torres and Longo 2013). It was listed as Threatened on the U.S. Endangered Species List in 1997 and its recovery plan was released in 2004 (USFWS 2004).

Conservation Needed
In view of the negative effects of anthropogenic climate change on this species and its habitat, national and global policies are needed to curb the use of and reliance on fossil fuels. Protection and restoration of the habitat of this species is urgently needed. Economic development should not be granted priority over currently federally protected natural resource areas in Puerto Rico and the protected status of such lands should be maintained. Community education and awareness programmes aimed to generate knowledge of and appreciation for Puerto Rico's endemic amphibians are recommended (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Research Needed
Future studies should assess the genetic diversity and patterns of gene flow (i.e. connectivity) between subpopulations (López-Torres and Longo 2013). Additional research and monitoring is needed, including efforts to understand the species-specific response to Bd and the effects of climate change (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because of an observed and projected population decline of more than 80% over a 10 year period (2017–2027) due to ongoing habitat loss, the effects of climate change (e.g. increasing severity, duration and frequency of hurricanes), and potentially chytridiomycosis; and because its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 99 km2, all individuals occur in one threat-defined location, and there is an ongoing decline in the extent and quality of this species' habitat and number of mature individuals.
habitat: It occurs in forest and along forest edges or openings, retreating by day into bromeliads or under moss and rocks. It has not been recorded outside forest habitats. Eggs are laid in bromeliads, and it breeds by direct development.
threats:
In the past, extensive deforestation took place over much of Puerto Rico due to agricultural expansion and wood-cutting. Current disturbances within the species' distribution include clearcutting of mountain tops to make way for radio communication facilities, even in protected areas (R. Joglar pers. comm. 2020). 

As a high-altitude species, it might also be susceptible to chytridiomycosis. Historical sampling for the amphibian chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd), revealed that specimens were infected with Bd at El Yunque in 1976 and 1983; however, the current status of Bd infection for this species is unknown (P. Burrowes pers. comm. 2020). 

The passing of the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management, and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA) in 2016 to address Puerto Rico’s economic crisis has created a new level of uncertainty about the future of public protected areas on the island as control over decision making is transferred from local authorities to an unelected board of financial managers (Snow 2017, Castro-Prieto et al. 2019). It is feared that this change might favor economic activities that will facilitate land use changes, driving the destruction and degradation of important habitats, and negatively impacting both biodiversity and human populations across Puerto Rico who depend on healthy and intact ecosystems for survival (Puerto Rico Red List Workshop June 2020).

The Caribbean region shows evidence of climate warming at regional (Peterson et al. 2002, Stephenson et al. 2014, IPCC 2018) and local scales (Burrowes et al. 2004, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). Precipitation patterns are not as clear, but some studies have shown a significant drying trend (Nurse et al. 2001, Neelin et al. 2006, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). The frequency of extreme events like hurricanes, heavy rains, landslides, and droughts has increased significantly in the last decade (Méndez-Lázaro et al. 2014, Oppenheimer et al. 2019) and may continue to rise in the future (IPCC 2014, 2018). Due to characteristics intrinsic to their biology and physiology, patterns of recent climate change in the Caribbean are expected to be unfavorable to this species, and the increasing frequency, severity and duration of hurricanes are especially detrimental to it (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). Climate warming and drought have been associated with a decrease in arthropods (Lister and Garcia 2018), an important food item for frogs; however, there have been doubts regarding the methodology used by Lister and Garcia (2018) (see Willig et al. 2019). The effects of climate change can also be associated with an increased risk of chytridiomycosis (Longo et al. 2010).

While some studies have shown that Small Indian Mongoose (Urva auropunctata) prey upon native coquis, only a small proportion (~1%) of their stomach contents include amphibians (Wolcott 1953, Pimentel 1955, Viella 1998). The introduced Cuban Tree Frog (Osteopilus septentrionalis) is a generalist predator that may include coquis in its diet, however the proportion of amphibians found in stomach content analysis (3.5%) is also low (Glorioso et al. 2010). This information suggests that the relative threat level of introduced predators on this species is low (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
population:
The species showed a significant range contraction for the lower end of the elevation distribution (-615 m asl; Campos-Cerqueira and Aide 2017) and a well-defined pattern of extirpation at low elevation areas (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). In El Verde Field Station, the species was relatively common prior to 1990, but is now locally extinct (Campos and Aide 2017). A 7% declining trend has been observed on a single study site in El Yunque National Forest from 1996 to 2020 (R. Joglar and A. Ríos-Franceschi unpubl. data).

This species was last observed in 2016 when it was found to be uncommon in Carite State Forest (only detected in 1 of 30 sites surveyed; López Hernández), but following Hurricane Maria in 2017, surveys have not been successful in detecting the species again and it may now be extirpated from this area (A. Puente and R. Joglar pers. comms. 2020). A similar pattern has occurred in the Cordillera Central, it seems to have disappeared due to the effects of climate change, including increasing severity and frequency of hurricanes. The population is suspected to have declined and is expected to continue to decline at a rate of at least 80% over a ten year period from 2017–2027 (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
range: This species has a restricted range in the interior uplands in Puerto Rico. <span id="docs-internal-guid-1946afbe-7fff-0d37-4528-4b9fc83c3575">Historically, it occurred at elevations between 39–1,045 m asl, but is now only found between 654–1,049 m asl, suggesting a significant range contraction of the lower elevational limit (Campos-Cerqueira and Aide 2017). It has been extirpated from sites in the Cordillera Central and Carite State Forest, and it is now only thought to occur at high-elevations of El Yunque National Forest (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020) in a single threat defined location, and with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 99 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Historically this species occurred in a few protected areas, Carite State Forest, Toro Negro State Forest, Maricao State Forest and Los Picachos State Forest; however, it is now only thought to occur at high-elevations of El Yunque National Forest (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Conservation Needed
Economic development should not be granted priority over currently federally protected natural resource areas in Puerto Rico and the protected status of such lands should be maintained. Buffer zones should be established to help ensure that land use activities do not threaten the integrity of the core protected areas. In view of the negative effects of anthropogenic climate change on this species and its habitat, national and global policies are needed to curb the use of and reliance on fossil fuels. Community education and awareness programmes aimed to generate knowledge of and appreciation for Puerto Rico's endemic amphibians are recommended (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Research Needed
A  range-wide assessment of all historical sites is needed, and is of particular importance after hurricanes. Careful population monitoring is required. More research is needed to better understand the species-specific response to the effects of climate change (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 429 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the interior uplands of Puerto Rico and ongoing decline in the number of mature individuals inferred from chytridiomycosis.
habitat: It is an arboreal species inhabiting mesic broadleaf forests. Males call from tree trunks and the canopy, eggs are laid in tree trunk cavities, and breeding is by direct development.
threats:
The Caribbean region shows evidence of climate warming at regional (Peterson et al. 2002, Stephenson et al. 2014, IPCC 2018) and local scales (Burrowes et al. 2004, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). Precipitation patterns are not as clear, but some studies have shown a significant drying trend (Nurse et al. 2001, Neelin et al. 2006, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). The frequency of extreme events like hurricanes, heavy rains, landslides, and droughts has increased significantly in the last decade (Méndez-Lázaro et al. 2014, Oppenheimer et al. 2019) and may continue to rise in the future (IPCC 2014, 2018). Due to characteristics intrinsic to their biology and physiology, patterns of recent climate change in the Caribbean are expected to be unfavorable to this species. Climate warming and drought have been associated with a decrease in arthropods (Lister and Garcia 2018), an important food item for frogs; however, there have been doubts regarding the methodology used by Lister and Garcia (2018) (see Willig et al. 2019). The effects of climate change can also be associated with an increased risk of chytridiomycosis (Longo et al. 2010). There is so far no evidence that this species is infected with Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis; however, it is occurs sympatrically at El Yunque with other species that have high prevalence of this chytrid pathogen, and thus, chytridiomycosis it is considered a threat (P. Burrowes pers. comm. 2020). 

The passing of the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management, and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA) in 2016 to address Puerto Rico’s economic crisis has created a new level of uncertainty about the future of public protected areas on the island as control over decision making is transferred from local authorities to an unelected board of financial managers (Snow 2017, Castro-Prieto et al. 2019). It is feared that this change might favor economic activities that will facilitate land use changes, driving the destruction and degradation of important habitats, and negatively impacting both biodiversity and human populations across Puerto Rico who depend on healthy and intact ecosystems for survival (Puerto Rico Red List Workshop June 2020).

While some studies have shown that Small Indian Mongoose (Urva auropunctata) prey upon native coquis, only a small proportion (~1%) of their stomach contents include amphibians (Wolcott 1953, Pimentel 1955, Viella 1998). The introduced Cuban Tree Frog (Osteopilus septentrionalis) is a generalist predator that may include coquis in its diet, however the proportion of amphibians found in stomach content analysis (3.5%) is also low (Glorioso et al. 2010). This information suggests that the relative threat level of introduced predators on this species is low (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
population: There are indications that populations have declined over the last three decades, even in suitable habitat (R. Joglar pers. comm. 2004). This species is possibly extirpated from Toro Negro in the Cordillera Central as evidenced by exhaustive surveys over several years, including surveys from 2005–2019 (A. Rios Franceschi pers. comm. 2020) and during 2013-2016 (D. Davila pers. comm. 2020). It is still locally common in El Yunque National Forest (Campos-Cerqueira and Aide 2017; R. Joglar, D. Davila, A. Longo and A. Puente pers. comms. 2020), and was heard calling in Carite State Forest one month after Hurricane Maria in 2017 (D. Davila pers. comm. 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is patchily distributed in the interior uplands of Puerto Rico. It has an elevational range of 329–1,152 m asl. In El Yunque National Forest, this species was historically found at elevations between 329–649 m asl, but is now only occurs between 362–1,020 m asl, suggesting a significant elevational range shift (Campos-Cerqueira and Aide 2017). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 429 km<sup>2</sup>, which represents five or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It occurs in several protected areas, including Carite State Forest and El Yunque National Forest. 

Conservation Needed
Economic development should not be granted priority over currently federally protected natural resource areas in Puerto Rico and the protected status of such lands should be maintained. Buffer zones should be established to help ensure that land use activities do not threaten the integrity of the core protected areas. In view of the negative effects of anthropogenic climate change on this species and its habitat, national and global policies are needed to curb the use of and reliance on fossil fuels. Community education and awareness programmes aimed to generate knowledge of and appreciation for Puerto Rico's endemic amphibians are recommended (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Research Needed
The species requires careful population monitoring. Surveys at all historical sites are needed and are of particular importance following hurricanes. More research is needed to better understand the species-specific response to the effects of climate change (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 4,064 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the interior uplands of Puerto Rico and ongoing decline in the number of mature individuals inferred from chytridiomycosis.
habitat: It is terrestrial in mesic forests. It has been heard calling from inside disturbed forest in El Yunque and Carite immediately following Hurricane Maria (2017). Males call from the ground or low vegetation. Eggs are laid in rotten logs, and develop directly.
threats:
The cause of the apparent decline in the population during the 1990s is not understood, but it is thought that chytridiomycosis linked with climate change played a role. Individuals tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) using qPCR in Carite State Forest with prevalence of 55% (Burrowes et al. 2008), and also at El Yunque National Forest in 2016 with a prevalence of 66% (P.A. Burrowes unpubl. data 2020). 

The Caribbean region shows evidence of climate warming at regional (Peterson et al. 2002, Stephenson et al. 2014, IPCC 2018) and local scales (Burrowes et al. 2004, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). Precipitation patterns are not as clear, but some studies have shown a significant drying trend (Nurse et al. 2001, Neelin et al. 2006, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). The frequency of extreme events like hurricanes, heavy rains, landslides, and droughts has increased significantly in the last decade (Méndez-Lázaro et al. 2014, Oppenheimer et al. 2019) and may continue to rise in the future (IPCC 2014, 2018). Due to characteristics intrinsic to their biology and physiology, patterns of recent climate change in the Caribbean are expected to be unfavorable to this species. Climate warming and drought have been associated with a decrease in arthropods (Lister and Garcia 2018), an important food item for frogs; however, there have been doubts regarding the methodology used by Lister and Garcia (2018) (see Willig et al. 2019). The effects of climate change can also be associated with an increased risk of chytridiomycosis (Longo et al. 2010). 

The passing of the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management, and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA) in 2016 to address Puerto Rico’s economic crisis has created a new level of uncertainty about the future of public protected areas on the island as control over decision making is transferred from local authorities to an unelected board of financial managers (Snow 2017, Castro-Prieto et al. 2019). It is feared that this change might favor economic activities that will facilitate land use changes, driving the destruction and degradation of important habitats, and negatively impacting both biodiversity and human populations across Puerto Rico who depend on healthy and intact ecosystems for survival (Puerto Rico Red List Workshop June 2020). 

While some studies have shown that Small Indian Mongoose (Urva auropunctata) prey upon native coquis, only a small proportion (~1%) of their stomach contents include amphibians (Wolcott 1953, Pimentel 1955, Viella 1998). The introduced Cuban Tree Frog (Osteopilus septentrionalis) is a generalist predator that may include coquis in its diet, however the proportion of amphibians found in stomach content analysis (3.5%) is also low (Glorioso et al. 2010). This information suggests that the relative threat level of introduced predators on this species is low (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
population:
The population experienced enigmatic declines in the early 1990s. It has not recolonized some areas at El Yunque National Forest, where the species was abundant in the past, and it is still very scarce in that forest (Joglar et al. 2011). The species remains extirpated below 654 m asl (Campos and Aide 2017; R. Joglar pers. comm. 2020). 

It has been observed recently in Maricao State Forest, where it appears to be abundant (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020), and in Carite State Forest, where individuals have been heard calling (D. Davila pers. comm. 2020, A. Puente pers. comm. 2020). It no longer occurs at El Tallonal, even though the status of the habitat has not changed (R. Joglar and A. Puente pers. comms. 2020). It has been absent from Toro Negro State Forest for 15–20 years (F. Bird pers. comm. 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species has a patchy distribution in the interior uplands of Puerto Rico. Historically, it occurred at elevations between 39–1,152 m asl, but is now only found between 654–800 m asl, suggesting a significant range contraction for both the lower and upper elevational distributions (Campos-Cerqueira and Aide 2017). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 4,064 km<sup>2</sup>, which represents five or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is known to occur in several protected areas, including El Yunque National Forest, Carite State Forest and Maricao State Forest.

Conservation Needed
Economic development should not be granted priority over currently federally protected natural resource areas in Puerto Rico and the protected status of such lands should be maintained. Buffer zones should be established to help ensure that land use activities do not threaten the integrity of the core protected areas (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). In view of the negative effects of anthropogenic climate change on this species and its habitat, national and global policies are needed to curb the use of and reliance on fossil fuels. Community education and awareness programmes aimed to generate knowledge of and appreciation for Puerto Rico's endemic amphibians are recommended (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Research Needed
Further research and survey work, including population monitoring, is needed to evaluate factors associated with past declines. More research is needed to better understand the species-specific response to the effects of climate change (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 74 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in one threat-defined location, there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Sierra de Luquillo, Puerto Rico.
habitat: It lives underground in elfin forest, and males call from root cavities of various trees. It has not been recorded outside of forest. Reproduction occurs by direct development.
threats:
The Caribbean region shows evidence of climate warming at regional (Peterson et al. 2002, Stephenson et al. 2014, IPCC 2018) and local scales (Burrowes et al. 2004, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). Precipitation patterns are not as clear, but some studies have shown a significant drying trend (Nurse et al. 2001, Neelin et al. 2006, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). The frequency of extreme events like hurricanes, heavy rains, landslides, and droughts has increased significantly in the last decade (Méndez-Lázaro et al. 2014, Oppenheimer et al. 2019) and may continue to rise in the future (IPCC 2014, 2018). Due to characteristics intrinsic to their biology and physiology, patterns of recent climate change in the Caribbean are expected to be unfavorable to this species. Climate warming and drought have been associated with a decrease in arthropods (Lister and Garcia 2018), an important food item for frogs; however, there have been doubts regarding the methodology used by Lister and Garcia (2018) (see Willig et al. 2019).

The effects of climate change can also be associated with an increased risk of chytridiomycosis (Longo et al. 2010). In 2007, three out of seven specimens from El Yunque (Mt. Britton site) tested positive for the amphibian chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) (Burrowes et al. 2008).

The passing of the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management, and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA) in 2016 to address Puerto Rico’s economic crisis has created a new level of uncertainty about the future of public protected areas on the island as control over decision making is transferred from local authorities to an unelected board of financial managers (Snow 2017, Castro-Prieto et al. 2019). It is feared that this change might favor economic activities that will facilitate land use changes, driving the destruction and degradation of important habitats, and negatively impacting both biodiversity and human populations across Puerto Rico who depend on healthy and intact ecosystems for survival (Puerto Rico Red List Workshop June 2020).

While some studies have shown that Small Indian Mongoose (Urva auropunctata) prey upon native coquis, only a small proportion (~1%) of their stomach contents include amphibians (Wolcott 1953, Pimentel 1955, Viella 1998). The introduced Cuban Tree Frog (Osteopilus septentrionalis) is a generalist predator that may include coquis in its diet, however the proportion of amphibians found in stomach content analysis (3.5%) is also low (Glorioso et al. 2010). This information suggests that the relative threat level of introduced predators on this species is low (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
population: Natural population fluctuations have been observed based on temperature and rainfall patterns; however the population is declining overall (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). A 10% decline has been observed at Mt. Britton since 1990 (R. Joglar. unpubl data) and monthly surveys throughout in El Yunque National Forest between 1990 and 2020 have revealed a slight declining trend (R. Joglar pers. comm. 2020).
range: This species has a very restricted distribution in the Sierra de Luquillo, Puerto Rico. Its elevational range is from 523–1,200 m asl, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 74 km<sup>2</sup>, and all individuals are considered to occur at a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It occurs in El Yunque National Forest.

Conservation Needed
Economic development should not be granted priority over currently federally protected natural resource areas in Puerto Rico and the protected status of such lands should be maintained. Buffer zones should be established to help ensure that land use activities do not threaten the integrity of the core protected areas (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). In view of the negative effects of anthropogenic climate change on this species and its habitat, national and global policies are needed to curb the use of and reliance on fossil fuels. Community education and awareness programmes aimed to generate knowledge of and appreciation for Puerto Rico's endemic amphibians are recommended (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Research Needed
Long-term studies such as monitoring programmes are required to evaluate its population status. Studies are needed to better understand the species-specific response to the effects of climate change (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

rationale: This species is assessed as Least Concern based on its widespread distribution in Australia. However, it should be noted that the population within the Murray-Darling basin is probably in decline and of conservation concern.
habitat:
This species inhabits the vegetated margins of rivers, lakes, creeks and swamps (Allen and Burgess 1990). It is usually found in waters ~1 m deep, with little or no flow, near overhanging vegetation, and especially in backwaters (Hansen 1999). It is most commonly found amongst logs, dead branches and macrophytes (Allen 1996).

Both males and females are mature at one year of age, live for two to four years, and females live longer than males. Spawning occurs from October to December, when water temperature reaches 22–23°C. Fecundity is usually 200–700 eggs, although a 49 mm long female has been reported to contain 2,350 eggs. The eggs are small (0.7 mm diameter), adhesive and attach to aquatic plants and rocks on the stream bed. Hatching occurs in five to seven days at 22°C, and larvae are approximately 3 mm long at hatching (Pusey et al. 2004).
threats: This species has suffered reduced distribution and abundance within its range in the Murray-Darling Basin (Harris and Gehrke 1997). It is most likely that a combination of various environmental pressures has led to the decline. The decline in aquatic macrophytes, removal of woody debris, associated pressures of alien species (particularly Eastern Gambusia and Redfin Perch), thermal pollution and the loss of the natural flow regime have all contributed to the removal of this species from most floodplain and riverine habitats within the Murray-Darling Basin (Morris et al. 2001).
population:
This species has experienced significant declines across much of historical range in the Murray-Darling Basin. Extirpation has occurred in SA and VIC and it may be lost from the Warrego River in Qld as well. A locally abundant, but highly geographically limited population exists in the Bogan River, mid Lachlan River, and the lower Gwydir River also has one known locality. The species is patchy and sometimes abundant in parts of the Border Rivers region, while it is common in parts of the Condamine River. The cause of the decline of this species is not well understood, part of it could be due to predation by Eastern Gambusia and Redfin Perch, but part of it could be due to reduced macrophyte cover.

The overall population trend is relatively stable but populations in the Murray-Darling Basin are potentially in decline.
range:
This species is relatively widespread, occurring in coastal and inland drainages of eastern Australia. This species is also present on Fraser Island and North Stradbroke Island off the coast of south-eastern Queensland. It was previously widespread, although patchily distributed, throughout much of the Murray-Darling Basin but is now thought to be extinct in Victoria and South Australia (Morris et al. 2000, Hammer and Butler 2002). It is generally patchily distributed and uncommon in the New South Wales and Queensland portions of the Murray-Darling, except for northern tributaries such as the Condamine River (Wager 1993, Morris et al. 2000).

This species is generally widespread but uncommon toward the northern end of its distribution in the Wet Tropics region (Russell and Hales 1993, Russell et al. 1996, Jebreen et al. 2002). This species is widely distributed in central and south-eastern Queensland and occurs in New South Wales south to the region around Coffs Harbour. Populations north of the Ayr region in northern Queensland have been flagged as being a distinct species to A. agassizii (Unmack et al. unpublished genetic data).
useTrade: This species is not used in the fishery industry but is a small part of the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There is infrequent monitoring in the Murray-Darling Basin, which is the only region of conservation concern for this species.

rationale: Although Schizothorax richardsonii is widely distributed along the Himalayan foothills and previous studies have indicated that it is abundantly and commonly found, recent observations over the last 5 to 10 years indicate drastic declines in many areas of its range due to introduction of exotics, damming and overfishing. While in some areas the declines are more than 90%, the over all reduction is inferred to be less than 50% with similar rates predicted in the future. The species is therefore assessed as Vulnerable. However, there is a strong belief that if alien species introductions are carried out throughout its range, this species may completely be displaced by exotic salmonids.
habitat: This species inhabits rivers, prefers to live among rocks and is primarily a bottom feeder, preferably near big submerged stones. It feeds on algal slimes, detritus and insects encrusted on the rocks (W. Vishwanath pers. comm., Shreshta 1990). It breeds during April-May, before the monsoon flood the rivers and streams; the fry grows to such a size as to bear the rigours of the flood waters.
threats: Introduction of exotic salmonids in hill streams and reservoirs of the Himalayan foothills are a serious threat (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.). Fishing for ornamental trade is a threat in Nagaland (Remadevi pers. comm.) and fishing for food is a general threat in northeastern India (W. Vishwanath pers. comm.).
population: This is a widespread and sometimes abundant species in the Himalayan foothills of Indus, Ganges and Brahmaputra river basins (W. Vishwanath pers. comm.). However, the species is undergoing rapid declines in several locations along the distribution range due to several anthropogenic threats such as dams, overfishing, tourism, alien species introductions, and in some areas fishing for ornamental purposes. It is rare in Ladakh (Sivakumar 2008). Local fishermen in Kashmir have observed dramatic declines (>90%) in the last five years due to rampant release of exotic salmonids (M. Arunachalam pers. comm.). The species is observed to be declining throughout its range, but there is no empirical study conducted (W. Vishwanath pers. comm.).
range: Schizothorax richardsonii is distributed in India, Nepal, Bhutan, Pakistan and Afghanistan. In India, it is found in Uttarakhand (Ramganga River; Joshi 1994, Negi and Negi 2010), Uttar Pradesh (Dehra Dun, Tehri, Pauri, Uttarkashi, Chamoli, Nainital, Almora, Pithoragarh), Nagaland (Dzulakie, Chokla, Dzuna, Tepuiki, Tesuru, Tizu, Zungki; Remadevi pers. comm.) and Jammu and Kashmir (in Indus drainage, Gulmarg; M. Arunachalam pers. comm.). In Nepal, it occurs in Janakpur, Bagmati and Narayani zones.
useTrade: This species is a valuable game fish. Due to its bottom feeding behaviour, the bait should be tied with a weight so that it remains at the bottom of the water, preferably near big stones (Jha and Rahamajhi pers. comm.).
conservationActions: This species requires urgent protection and proactive conservation efforts to save it from becoming extinct in most of its range. There is an urgent need to stop the release of exotics in the upland areas throughout its range (M. Arunachalam, Remadevi and W. Vishwanath pers. comm.).

rationale:
In Italy the wild population is most likely extinct as the species almost totally depends upon stocking and there is no evidence of spawning from stocked or wild individuals (the last known natural spawning probably occurred early 1980s). The few animals occasionally captured in the wild are probably from aquaculture origin and were probably released in the last few years. However, there is a slim chance that wild individuals still exist. The population on the eastern Adriatic are also probably extinct in the wild, there is no evidence of natural reproduction since 1990 in Albania. However, there also is a slim chance that wild individuals still exist there.

The species is assessed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) under criterion A2, on the basis of an estimated population decline of greater than 80% (possibly 100%) in the past three generations (60 years). This population decline is based on a decline in the extent of occurrence (EOO), area of occupancy (AOO), and catch data, and was caused by over-harvesting (both legal and illegal), loss of access to spawning grounds (dams), and pollution (industrial and agricultural).

The remaining potential suitable spawning grounds are restricted to very few areas in the Po River with an AOO of less than 10 km² (one location). There may still be some wild individuals left, but it is unknown how many there may be; potentially there are less than 250. Without continuous re-stocking the survival of this species is doubtful as continued successful reproduction in the wild can no longer be confirmed.

For the EU 27 region, the species is also assessed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) (CR(PE) A2bcde;B2ab(i,ii,iii,iv,v)).
habitat: The Adriatic Sturgeon lives in large rivers where, in the past, reproduction occurred from May to July. It is a long-lived, anadromous species, living mainly in the rivers. It spawns in freshwater after a marine period of growth during which it remains near the shore (at the mouths of the rivers) at a depth of 10–40 m. The upstream migration into Italian rivers occurs during the first months of the year (Paccagnella 1948, D'Ancona 1924). It occurs over sandy or muddy bottoms. The only remaining suitable spawning areas for this species are at the confluence between the Po River and its tributaries (Adda, Ticino etc).
threats: Overfishing (both legal and illegal), and in particular of pre-reproductive sized fish, threatens this species. It is also threatened by the creation of barriers to its migratory routes, which reduce its reproductive success; and fragmentation of populations, particularly by dams for hydropower on the Po River (Isola Serafini's Dam, Piacenza). Water pollution, the Allee effect, and competition for habitats with allochthonous species (Silurus glanis) also threaten the future survival of this sturgeon.
population:
Artificial reproduction in fish farms has been effective and successful since 1988 (Arlati et al. 1988), and the species is continuously restocked in Italy. However, there is no evidence to confirm successful reproduction in the wild. The presence of natural populations in Italy cannot be excluded completely because of some sporadic catches of individuals of possible wild origin. Spawning has not been recorded at suspected spawning grounds over the past 15 years. A land-locked population seems to be present in the river Ticino but it remains unclear whether the occasionally caught individuals originate from escapees or stockings.

A genetic comparison between Italian and Albanian samples collected some decades ago showed a high level of diversification and suggested that the different populations should be considered as distinct conservation units (Ludwig et al. 2003).

The species was reintroduced to Greece (Pascos et al. 2003), but there is no evidence that it has established a viable population. It is considered as regionally extinct in Croatia, Albania and Montenegro.

Of approximately 2,000 specimens of A. naccarii fished in the Po River and sold at the fish market between 1981 and 1988, more than 80% of the specimens weighed less than 3.5 kg, having been taken before the reproductive phase (Rossi et al. 1991).
range:
This sturgeon was present exclusively in the southern part of Europe. Apparently it is restricted to the Adriatic Sea area, and in particular to the fresh waters of the northern part of Italy and the eastern coasts of the Adriatic Sea.

Historically the species was present in the sea from Venice and Trieste, to Greece and Corfù (Berg 1932); and in the Venetian lagoons during fall (Faber 1883). It was recorded in the rivers Adige, Brenta, Bacchiglione, Livenza, Piave, Tagliamento, and Po (and its affluents); once it was recorded up to Turin (Festa 1892); at Carignano and Carmagnola (Delmastro 1982); and in the Po delta (Tortonese 1989, Paccagnella 1948, D'Ancona 1924, Pavesi 1907); in the Ticino and Adda rivers (Bernini and Nardi 1989, 1990); along the Albanian coasts (Filipini et al. 1956); and Croatia (Mrakovic et al. 1995), Bosnia-Herzegovina and Montenegro (Lake Skadar). It was last recorded from Albania in 1997 in the Buna River (Ludwig et al. 2003). There is evidence that the species was previously found in Greece (Economidis 1973) but it is no longer known there. It was reintroduced to Greece (Pascos et al. 2003) but there is no evidence that it has established a viable population. There have been conflicting opinions regarding its presence in Spain.

At present, as a consequence of a recovery plan carried out by several public institutions from 1990 to 2007, specimens have been recorded in the Po River and its inflow rivers (Ticino, Adda, Oglio, Mincio), and in the rivers Adige, Livenza, Piave, Tagliamento. The Isola Serafini Dam on the middle of the Po River, prevents the migratory movements of the downstream populations into the upstream part of the river. There is no evidence available for natural spawning of wild or released individuals.
useTrade: Pure A. nacarii are not traded much; it is used more to produce hybrids with other sturgeon species, which are traded. Subsistence catches of this species for food is illegal.
conservationActions:
The species A. naccarii is listed in Annex 2 of the Council Directive 92/43/EEC of 21 May 1992 on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora of community interest whose conservation requires the designation of special areas of conservation. This species was also listed on CITES Appendix II in 1998.

Together with other sturgeon species that once were present in Italy (A. sturio and Huso huso), the capture of the species is forbidden by law in the regions of the Padana valley, Lombardia, Emilia Romagna and Veneto.

Artificial reproduction in fish farm (ex-situ) is effective and has been successful since 1988, from an original population caught from the wild in the 1970s and from F1, and the species is continuously restocked in Italy. However, there is no evidence to confirm continuing reproduction in the wild.

A recovery plan for this species has been carried out by several public administrations since the early 1990s, with scientific research and restocking actions of about a total of half millions of specimens of different size reintroduced in the public waters (rivers Adda, Oglio, Piave, Po). The last part of the plan was supported also by a Life project.

A project for a fish passage allowing to the fish to overcome the Isola Serafini's dam is under evaluation by the public authority. This project was proposed in occasion of the building of a new and bigger navigation lock close by the old one on the Po river, in the Province of Piacenza.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This species occurs from lowland to alpine zones in forests and grassland. It breeds in lakes, marshes, ponds, pools, and ditches, but also in streams by larval development. Breeding season is from April to May, or as late as July at higher elevations (Sato 1943, Sato and Matsui 2013). Most larvae metamorphose in July to August of the same year, but some larvae in cold habitat may overwinter and grow to a larger size (Sato and Matsui 2013). Mature individuals hibernate in winter, emerging as the snow melts and spend most of their time hidden under stones, logs etc. on forest floor near water (Tokuda 2015). The subpopulation in Lake Kuttara was known as the only neotenic population in this species, although it is considered to now be extinct (Sato and Matsui 2013).
threats: This species' habitat is generally in good condition in most areas, but populations near human habitations are decreasing due to the modification and desiccation of wetlands, expanding areas of human housing, farming, and road construction. Predation by alien species such as raccoons (Procyon lotor) is reported (Hori et al. 2013, Takenaka 2014). It is also reported that predation of toxic tadpoles of the introduced Japanese toads (Bufo japonicus formosus), which is now spreading in western and central Hokkaido, by larvae of Hynobius retardatus causes fatality (Kazila and Kishida 2019, Oyake et al. 2020), and this is a newly emerging, serious threat for this species.
population: This species is widely distributed and common in Hokkaido. It is abundant in areas that are not disturbed by human activity. It also occurs in flat lowland to hilly areas near human habitations, but these subpopulations have been decreasing in recent years due to urbanization. A neotenic subpopulation was known in Lake Kuttara (Sasaki 1924), but this subpopulation is now considered to be extinct because of predation by introduced trout (Sato and Matsui 2013).
range: In general, this species is widespread in Hokkaido, Japan, except for Nemuro Peninsula, and Kushiro Marsh in the eastern region. It occurs only in mainland Hokkaido, and there are no records from other Japanese islands (Sato and Matsui 2013). Its elevational range is from lowland to alpine zones between 3-1,870 m asl (Sato and Matsui 2013). However, local populations seem to not be continuous and there are significant geographical gaps in between (these are not represented on the map). The extent of occurrence of this species' distribution is 133,041 km2.
useTrade: Individuals collected from the wild are traded on the internet as a pet.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in some protected areas, Rishiri-Rebun, Shiretoko, Akan-Mashu, Kushiro-shitsugen, Daisetsuzan, Shikotsu-Toya National Parks and Shokanbetsu-Teuri-Yagishiri, Abashiri, Niseko-Shakotan-Otaru-kaigan, Hidaka-sanmyaku-Erimo, Onuma Quasi-National Parks. The species has been designated as Data Deficient in the Japanese Red List. 

Research Needed
Further research is needed to determine the distribution, population trend, and adverse effects of alien species. Long-term studies such as monitoring programmes are required to evaluate its population status.

rationale:
Marine Iguanas occur on the large islands of Española, Fernandina, Floreana, Genovesa, Isabela, Marchena, Pinta, San Cristobál, Santa Cruz, Santa Fé, and Santiago, the mid-sized islands of Baltra, Bartolomé, Pinzón, Plaza Norte, Plaza Sur, Rábida, and Seymour Norte, smaller key populations on Darwin, Roca Redonda, and Wolf, as well as many satellite islets of the Galápagos Archipelago, Ecuador. The estimated extent of occurrence is 56,647 km2 by minimum convex polygon and the area of occupancy is estimated at 42,155 km2 using a 2x2 km grid overlay within a coastal buffer 2 km from the shore. The population size is poorly known and crudely estimated as low as 33,000 total iguanas after a strong El Niño famine and as many as 350,000 after several years of La Niña abundant food conditions, with fewer than 210,000 mature individuals. Current taxonomy describes eleven subspecies. Only one subspecies has a genetically resilient effective population size, and only one more is close to the threshold to be considered healthy; the remaining are critically low to moderate. Overall population trend is unknown, but is subject to extreme fluctuations and reductions during El Niño events (10–90% mortality), which are predicted to intensify in the future with ongoing climate change.

Marine Iguana populations have been reduced by invasive alien predators such as feral cats, rats, and free-roaming pigs and dogs on five of the 13 main islands (ca 30% of the total population). These iguanas are threatened by a region-wide increase in human population and visitation that has multiplied the impacts from stress, marine pollution including oil and diesel spills, habitat degradation, and chance of further invasive species introductions and emergent diseases. Land-based tourist presence and intensity has been shown to have a significant overall negative effect on iguana health. Overall population trends are difficult to estimate without comprehensive population size monitoring data, however, the multitude of known anthropogenic threats found across the archipelago are sufficient to support an estimate of an overall population reduction of at least 30% over the last three generations. Without significant invasive species control and enhanced protection from marine pollution, declines are projected to continue in the near future, exacerbated by increasingly frequent and severe El Niño events and human impacts that affect all populations. We estimate that the per cent reduction over the past two generations and one generation into the future (ca 18–24 years) will also be at least 30%. This species qualifies for listing as Vulnerable.
habitat:
Marine Iguanas are the only lizard species that forage in the ocean. Adults and juveniles occur on rocky coasts and intertidal zones. Adult females can be found nesting up to 2 km inland and adult males can be found foraging in marine waters, up to depths of 30 m. They feed almost exclusively on marine algae, primarily three red genera (Centroceras, Gelidium, Pterocladia; Rubenstein and Wikelski 2003) and the green algal genus Ulva when exposed during low tides (Shepherd and Hawkes 2005). The majority of iguanas graze intertidally, though the largest iguanas of each colony also dive beneath the sea surface to forage on offshore algal beds (30 m offshore, 2–30 m depth; Buttemer and Dawson 1993, Wikelski and Trillmich 1994). Some iguana populations have been known to supplement their algal diet with highly salty land plants, primarily Saltwort (Batis maritima), but also other coastal succulents such as Sesuvium portulacastrum (Wikelski and Wrege 2000).
